properties.media:imagetext:
Chengtu, Sze.,
June 3, 1933.
Dear Miss
Smi th :
Your letter arrived by the first air mail
and brought a real thrill to its
recipient.
Unfortunately,
it was
delivered two hours after the plane had departed,
else I might have returned it with the same plane.
In accordance with your wishes, I am enclosing
herewith the original envelope and trust it may
enrich your
collector's archives.
not know if we are
the most interior
air mail for Asia or not.
the inauguration of the
service
is providing a real thrill to the populace and great convenience
to letter writing.
The plane had real difficulty in landing
on its first trip as the
populace was too enthusiastic and
almost provided a human carpet for the landing.
In spite of
care several deaths occurred due to the crowd
and trampling.
The landing field is in
the city but I understand that the
pilots are
seeking a larger field which may take them out of
the city.
Last November when some of Liu Sian's military
bombing planes soared over the city was to many
the first
plane they had
seen.
The mail planes seem a great change
in purpose to these folks.
War continues outside the city.
trip to Kwanhsien to visit the plain's water supply.
You re that your
and is much fighting between the 24th and 28th Armus,
One faction was inside the city and the other across the river.
In order to prevent crossing the dykes have been cut
allowing the water to wander where it will.
Many fields
hopelessly flooded, while others are drying for want of
water.
Prices of
commodities have risen gretly.
To the northwest
and to the southwest many bridges
have been burned and
destroyed.
settlement does not come soon, foreigners may
have to summer in Chengtu.
Last summer I had a most interesting trip to
Tatsienliu and beyond.
My hiking took me right to the foot of
the famous Minya Konga.
I did not see any Tibetan spoons
and upon inquiry of the foreign residents there found that
they had not actually seen such styles in use.
I was hoping to
fulfill your wish for one.
The scenery all thru the trip
was wonderful.
I would recommend it to any mountain minded
folk coming
Again with most
pleasant memories
of your
visit to us here and with best wishes to Miss Hinder and
yourself,
Most cordially,
(Sga) VICTORIA R. PETERSON
SYdo./SIPos
